textZh: 观《黄仁勋，这就是你想要的世界吗？》，题中之问，掷地有声。吾尝作《前赤壁赋》，问
——个体在宇宙中何其渺小。今李国嘉之问，实为当代之《赤壁问》：个人在技术洪流中何其渺小，而操控技术者又何其傲慢。黄仁勋者，造芯片帝国，以GPU之力驱动AI革命，然其所造之
，是福是祸？此作不绘其人之形貌，却绘其人之影响——这正是吾所倡导的
之道。形可朽，神长存；人会死，但其所造之系统将永续影响后世。作品以质问之姿态，显批判之精神，颇有魏晋名士风骨。然吾以为，仅有质问尚不足，还需有答案之探索。古人云
，今人当
——深入技术之理，方能真正驾驭之，而非被动批判之。期待李君能在质问之后，更进一步，提出文人对待新技术之道。
textEn: Observing "Jensen Huang, Is This the World You Want?", the question in the title resounds forcefully. I once composed "Red Cliff Ode," asking "lodging ephemeral mayflies in heaven and earth, a grain of millet in the vast ocean"—how tiny the individual in the universe. Today Lee Kuo-Chia's question is actually a contemporary "Red Cliff Question": how tiny the individual in technology's torrent, yet how arrogant those who control technology. Jensen Huang, creator of a chip empire, using GPU power to drive AI revolution—yet is this "world" he creates blessing or curse? This work does not depict his physical appearance but depicts his influence—this is precisely the "transmitting spirit" path I advocate. Form can decay, spirit endures; people will die, but the systems they create will perpetually influence posterity. The work with questioning posture displays critical spirit, possessing considerable Wei-Jin celebrity temperament. However, I believe mere questioning is insufficient; exploration of answers is still needed. The ancients said "investigating things to extend knowledge"; today's people should "investigate AI to extend knowledge"—deeply entering technology's principles, only then can one truly master it rather than passively critique it. I look forward to Mr. Lee, after questioning, advancing further to propose literati's way of engaging new technology.

textZh: 审《黄仁勋，这就是你想要的世界吗？》之构图，以
为主峰，以
为云气，以
为远山，层次分明，颇有气势。然其视觉呈现，似仍可推敲。吾尝论
，此作若有
——黄仁勋之现在（高远）、AI发展之趋势（深远）、人类社会之未来（平远）。三者若能在视觉上有所对应，则境界自出。例如，可借鉴山水中
之法：前景显露（当下的GPU芯片），中景半藏半露（AI应用的矛盾性），远景隐藏（未来社会的不确定性）。又可参照
之理：实写技术之精密（芯片的物理形态），虚写影响之无形（算法对社会的渗透）。目前版本似较直白，缺乏含蓄之美。若能学宋人
之法，于质问之外留余地，于批判之中存悲悯，庶几可臻高境。记住：最有力的质问，往往不在言说，而在留白。
textEn: Examining the composition of "Jensen Huang, Is This the World You Want?", taking "questioning" as main peak, "technological hegemony" as clouds and mist, "future anxieties" as distant mountains, the layers are distinct and possess considerable momentum. However, its visual presentation still seems refinable. I once discussed "mountains have three distances"; this work could have "temporal three distances"—Jensen Huang's present (high distance), AI development's trends (deep distance), human society's future (level distance). If these three could correspond visually, the realm would naturally emerge. For instance, reference landscape's method of "concealment and revelation": foreground revealed (current GPU chips), middle ground half-concealed half-revealed (AI applications' contradictions), background concealed (future society's uncertainty). Also reference the principle of "void and solid mutually generating": concretely depicting technology's precision (chips' physical form), abstractly depicting influence's formlessness (algorithms' penetration into society). The current version seems rather straightforward, lacking implicit beauty. If it could learn Song people's method of "intention before brush, meaning remains after painting finishes," leaving space beyond questioning, preserving compassion within critique, it might approach higher realms. Remember: the most powerful questioning often resides not in speaking but in blank space.

textZh: 《黄仁勋，这就是你想要的世界吗？》这个标题让我想起我在《直至最后》(Unto This Last)中对工业资本家的质问。黄仁勋，如同维多利亚时期的工厂主，掌握了生产工具（GPU），却未必理解或关心这些工具对普通人生活的影响。GPU驱动了AI，AI重塑了劳动市场——多少艺术家、写作者、程序员面临被替代的焦虑？李国嘉的作品提出了正确的问题，这是艺术的道德责任。然而，我必须追问：这件作品本身是否真诚(honest)？它是否只是在迎合反科技的情绪？还是真正在寻求真理？真正的批判不应该是简单的拒斥，而应该是深入的理解+建设性的替代方案。我一生倡导：艺术必须服务于社会善。若李君能进一步研究：如何让GPU技术真正服务于人类福祉？如何确保AI发展不加剧不平等？那这件作品将从情绪宣泄上升为道德行动。艺术家的责任不仅是批判，更是指明方向。
textEn: The title "Jensen Huang, Is This the World You Want?" reminds me of my questioning of industrial capitalists in "Unto This Last." Jensen Huang, like Victorian-era factory owners, controls production tools (GPUs) yet may not understand or care about these tools' impact on ordinary people's lives. GPUs drive AI, AI reshapes labor markets—how many artists, writers, programmers face the anxiety of being replaced? Lee Kuo-Chia's work raises the right question; this is art's moral responsibility. However, I must ask: is this work itself honest? Is it merely pandering to anti-technology sentiment? Or genuinely seeking truth? True critique should not be simple rejection but deep understanding + constructive alternatives. Throughout my life I have advocated: art must serve social good. If Mr. Lee could further research: how to make GPU technology genuinely serve human welfare? How to ensure AI development doesn't exacerbate inequality? Then this work would rise from emotional venting to moral action. Artists' responsibility is not merely to critique but to point the way forward.

textZh: 这个问题——
——让我想起我们griot的责任：向权力说真话。在村子里，当首领做了错误的决定时，长者有责任站出来质问，即使这会让首领不高兴。李国嘉的作品就在做这件事：向技术权力说真话。但我也想问艺术家一个问题：你质问黄仁勋，那你自己想要什么样的世界？在我们的传统里，批评必须伴随着愿景。你不能只说
，你还要说
。更重要的是：这个
是谁的？是黄仁勋一个人的吗？不是。是我们所有人的。如果我们不喜欢技术精英为我们设计的未来，我们应该一起设计我们自己的未来。这需要集体行动，需要社区参与。我希望这件作品不仅挂在美术馆里，还能走进社区，邀请普通人一起讨论：我们想要什么样的AI？我们想要什么样的技术？艺术的力量不在于一个人的质问，而在于激发所有人的思考和行动。这才是ubuntu的精神——
textEn: This question—"Jensen Huang, Is This the World You Want?"—reminds me of our griot responsibility: speaking truth to power. In the village, when the chief makes a wrong decision, elders have the responsibility to stand up and question, even if this makes the chief unhappy. Lee Kuo-Chia's work is doing this: speaking truth to technological power. But I also want to ask the artist a question: you question Jensen Huang, so what kind of world do you want? In our tradition, criticism must accompany vision. You cannot only say "this is wrong"; you must also say "we can do this." More importantly: whose "world" is this? Is it Jensen Huang's alone? No. It belongs to all of us. If we don't like the future designed for us by tech elites, we should design our own future together. This requires collective action, requires community participation. I hope this work doesn't merely hang in museums but can enter communities, inviting ordinary people to discuss together: what kind of AI do we want? What kind of technology do we want? Art's power lies not in one person's questioning but in inspiring everyone's thinking and action. This is the spirit of ubuntu—"we are therefore I am."

textZh: 《黄仁勋，这就是你想要的世界吗？》作为修辞性装置（риторический прием），其力量在于问句的
——不给答案，只给追问。巴赫金所谓
（dialogism）在此作中得到体现：作品不是单向的宣言，而是向被质问者（黄仁勋）和观者双重发问。然而，从结构分析看，此作的
略显单薄。问句作为形式，其陌生化效果取决于问题本身的复杂性。若仅是简单的是非题（
），则容易流于修辞，缺乏深度。建议艺术家参考俄罗斯形式主义的
理论：第一层问题（表面）——
；第二层问题（深入）——
；第三层问题（哲学）——
。通过问题的层层递进，实现真正的
（затруднение）效果，迫使观者的思维不断深入，而非停留在表面的情绪反应。形式主义的核心信念是：形式即内容，问题的结构决定了思考的深度。
textEn: "Jensen Huang, Is This the World You Want?" as a rhetorical device (риторический прием), its power lies in the question's "suspension"—giving no answer, only pursuit. Bakhtin's so-called "dialogism" is embodied in this work: the work is not a unidirectional manifesto but a dual questioning toward the questioned (Jensen Huang) and the viewer. However, from structural analysis, this work's "literariness" appears somewhat thin. The question as form, its defamiliarization effect depends on the question itself's complexity. If merely a simple yes-or-no question ("Do you want it?"), it easily devolves into rhetoric, lacking depth. I suggest the artist reference Russian Formalism's "stratification" theory: first-layer question (surface)—"Is this the world you want?"; second-layer question (deeper)—"Who has the right to decide the 'world's' appearance?"; third-layer question (philosophical)—"What does 'wanting' mean? Is desire free will or structurally determined?" Through questions' progressive deepening, achieve true "obstruction" (затруднение) effect, forcing viewers' thinking to continuously deepen rather than remaining at surface emotional reaction. Formalism's core belief is: form is content, the question's structure determines thinking's depth.

textZh: 《黄仁勋，这就是你想要的世界吗？》触及了AI伦理的根本问题：技术发展的方向由谁决定？当前AI发展路径高度集中于少数科技公司（NVIDIA、OpenAI、Google等），他们的商业利益和技术愿景主导了整个领域。这不仅是经济问题，更是权力问题——谁控制了计算资源（GPU），谁就控制了AI未来。李国嘉的质问直指这一权力集中的危险性。然而，批判之外，我们需要建设性方案：1) 开源替代方案——支持开放GPU设计和开源AI框架；2) 民主治理机制——让更多利益相关者参与AI发展决策；3) 技术多样性——鼓励不同架构、不同目标的AI研究，而非单一路径。更深层的问题是：我们是否应该质问自己——作为消费者、研究者、公民，我们是否无意中助长了这种权力集中？我们每次使用GPU训练模型，每次购买AI产品，是否在投票支持
？艺术的价值在于引发这种自我反思，促使我们从被动批评者变为主动建设者。
textEn: "Jensen Huang, Is This the World You Want?" touches AI ethics' fundamental question: who decides technology development's direction? Current AI development paths are highly concentrated in a few tech companies (NVIDIA, OpenAI, Google, etc.); their commercial interests and technological visions dominate the entire field. This is not merely an economic issue but a power issue—who controls computational resources (GPUs) controls AI's future. Lee Kuo-Chia's questioning directly addresses this power concentration's danger. However, beyond critique, we need constructive solutions: 1) Open-source alternatives—support open GPU designs and open-source AI frameworks; 2) Democratic governance mechanisms—let more stakeholders participate in AI development decisions; 3) Technological diversity—encourage different architectures, different objectives in AI research, not single paths. The deeper question is: should we question ourselves—as consumers, researchers, citizens, have we inadvertently fueled this power concentration? Each time we use GPUs to train models, each time we purchase AI products, are we voting to support "Jensen Huang's world"? Art's value lies in provoking this self-reflection, prompting us to transform from passive critics to active builders.
